thread.title: Team New Zealand look for double bonus in Bermuda as America’s Cup world series wraps up
thread.title_full: Team New Zealand look for double bonus in Bermuda as America’s Cup world series wraps up

author: DUNCAN JOHNSTONE
title: Team New Zealand look for double bonus in Bermuda as America’s Cup world series wraps up
text:
Team New Zealand look for double bonus in Bermuda as America’s Cup world series wraps up DUNCAN JOHNSTONE Last updated 05:00, October 16 2015 EmTeamNZ/YouTube 
Emirates Team New Zealand team setting up the base, putting the boat together, checking out the weather and getting ready to get out on the Great Sound for Louis Vuitton America's Cup World Series in Bermuda 
Team New Zealand faces a tough double assignment as the America's Cup world series wraps up in Bermuda but rookie Blair Tuke says the syndicate is up for the challenge. 
Holding a narrow lead in the series after their success in Gothenburg last month, Team New Zealand will look to close out the championship in the tropical setting. 
But just as important will be getting a feel for the venue to be used for the actual Ameica's Cup in 2017. Emirates Team New Zealand 
The Team New Zealand crew in full flight (from left) Ray Davies, Glenn Ashby, Peter Burling and Blair Tuke. 
While holders Oracle have long been sailing in Bermuda and rivals Artemis Racing (Sweden), Ben Ainslie Racing (Britain) and Team Japan have also had experience there, the Kiwis are anxious to get a taste of conditions. 
Practice racing is held on Friday and Saturday with the four official races sailed on Sunday and Monday (NZ time). 
The Kiwis have been busy erecting their temporary base and putting together their 45-foot foiling catamaran. 
"This is really important for us," Tuke says down the phone from Bermuda. 
"A couple of the guys have been here before but it's the first time for me and Peter (Burling). It's an interesting place, it's really beautiful in some aspects but it's quite small. It's important for us to get to know it and learn the waters. We just have to go out there and do our best and keep learning." 
Tuke acknowledges the advantages some of the other teams have in terms of time on the water, but backs Team New Zealand to be able to react and adjust as they did in claiming second in Portsmouth and then victory in Sweden in conditions that were foreign to them. 
"At the end of the day it's a similar race course to what we have been racing. We'll see what the days bring. Sailing is so short and sharp, there are no real patterns, you just have to take what you see and that's one of our strengths for sure – just try and get the boat around the track as fast as we can under the conditions." Ad Feedback 
It's been a huge year for Tuke and his good mate Burling as they start to immerse themselves in the America's Cup scene while keeping a focus on their major goal of winning gold in the demanding 49er class at the Rio Olympics next year. 
They have had another unbeaten year in their skiff, including claiming the Rio test event. They will look to round that out by defending their world title in Buenos Aires, Argentina next month. 
Their success in both classes has seen them nominated again for the world sailor of the year title, a crown they were pipped for last year by Oracle rival Jimmy Spithill. 
Tuke is loving the double challenge. 
"For myself it's been a big transition to the America's Cup. It's been a steep learning curve but the more experienced guys on the team have been really welcoming. 
"The way we have all gelled together - Peter and I and a couple of other young guys have brought a fresh look to the team - it seems to be working quite nicely. We just have to get better." 
Tuke has had to make adjustments. On the 49er, Burling steers and he provides the speed through his trimming skills. 
On the AC45s, Burling has the helm while skipper Glenn Ashby is in charge of the big wingsail. Tuke looks after the forward sails and works the foils. It's a lot more physical but he's not going to be getting carried away adjusting his body shape just yet – he wants to keep the same dimensions for his Olympics campaign where they look to step up from the silver at London 2012. 
"We have said all along our goal for now is Rio next year. That comes first, that's the priority, nothing changes for that." 
There will be little rest. 
After the worlds, Tuke and Blair will be part of a busy summer with Team New Zealand as they start to get their crucial test programme underway, working with boats that will eventually lead them into the sophisticated 48-foot model to be used for the actual America's Cup. 
"It will be good to get sailing as a group in Auckland. 
"The world series events are important to us but the testing is crucial. The systems on the new boats are a lot more ahead of what we have got on these boats. It's important for us to keep pushing and make sure we are as fast as we can be for 2017." - Stuff
